head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #21

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #21 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: a wider one appearing on the Lt pass'd 2 bays on Rt – turn'd 1st pt on Rt & pass'd a spacious opening of the lac on Lt – after turning the pt NWbW to a sandy pt of an Id on Lt then ½m same Co to a pt of Stones Lt – then 1½ to the pt of a long sandy Island on Lt same Co – then to a sandy pt on Rt 2m. Wt – then W3m. to the pt of an Id on Lt spacious lac & Islds on Lt & sevl other Islds in a cluster on Lt near the Co – (here we met 3 Canoes of Indians (mostly men) on their way to Alb. Fort – 2 of these were Chiefs, one of Sturgeon lac & ye other of lac Seul. We made them a present of Tobacco, Powder & Shot, with a Gall. keg of liquor, & as it is necessary to make friends with men of influence on the road – we encamp'd here according to their request some liquor was given them afterwds but they were tolerably peaceable on the whole & we parted very good friends. 'Tis true the best part of a day is lost, but as they Traded some Provisions with us, our men have no occasion to eat their corn, which from 8 sacks at Païs Plat, is reduc'd to less than two)[.] Lat. 50°22'No[.]

17 Saturday. From the pt on Lt ment'd yesterday, cross'd over to a pt on Rt Wb½ S2½m. many Isls & spacious lac to ye Lt – from hence a streight clear opening presents itself, like a large River, went W8m. to ye extreme pt on Rt sevl bays on Rt & Is on Lt – the pt on Rt in last Co is rocky & has small Isld before it – From the pt 3m. to a rocky pt on Rt sevl Islds at a distance on Lt[.] Lat. as yesterday 50°22'. (This morning we left the Inds early, but were oblig'd to embark the Guide in our Canoe, witht his Wife & Children she being drunk & unwilling to depart, this oblig'd us to wait for them at ye end of the Co accordingly they came up to us in the Evening; but the work of 2 fine days was lost, & this I must contribute entirely to our having Spirits with us, which is entirely unnecessary in a voyage, where Expidition is a primary object, on Acct of Provision[s] which I begin to be in pain for as it runs off very fast, notwithstanding we hav[e] 2 nets in the water at every opportunity, but the Provisions has been consumed by means unforeseen. A Guide must be had at all Events, & him & his family maintain'd, or he will not proceed, this has been as heavy upon our Stock as the men's allowance. It was the opinion of Mr Grant, that the less spirituous liquors we had with us the better, this was my opinion, & also the Opinion of the Traders we met at lac de petite Jour. (who were intelligent men)[.] An Indian may be as meek as a lamb when sober, & the same man when drunk a meer Devil, in short we have not had occasion for an hour uneasiness in all the rout, but wha[t] has proceeded from this infernal Stimulator: were we on a Trading voyage I own the necessity of it[.]

18 Sunday. From Turn'd the rocky pt mentd yesterday & went NWbW3m. to a pt on R[t] (the lac here appears narrower) then NWbW abt 1m. across ye lac, 'till we were in y[e] midway betw. 2 small Is of Stones (NB here are 3 small stony Is, but we took the Co between the 2 farthest) then NNW3m. to a conspicuous sandy pt on Lt – turn'd y[e] sandy pt & cross'd a bay 2m. to ye next pt on Lt Isls on Rt – then slanted over the adjo[…] bay, to a rocky pt on Rt being a broad Channel with Grass on Rt WbN3m. in it NWbN3m.1½ to a pt on Lt a bay on Rt – then 1m. along the pt (which is of wild rice) & from it a long view forward – from the pt of wild rice on Lt travers'd over 1½m t[o] a pt on Rt then NWbN3 to a small rocky I. with a few Trees of dead wood on it (this Isle I nam'd Isle des Groiselles, on Acct of its being entirely covd with them & most excellt Rasberries) many small Is on Lt & spacious lac on Rt – from I. des Grois

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
